title: U.S. Veterans' Transition to Civilian Life
subtitle: How it works, what resources exist, and common challenges (USA only)

content: Transition Assistance Program (TAP): Mandatory for most branches. Covers résumé writing, interviewing skills, financial planning, and an introduction to VA benefits (GI Bill, VA healthcare, etc.). Often includes a 'Benefits Briefing' where VA reps explain education, healthcare, and disability compensation.
Individualized Counseling: Many installations assign a Transition Specialist to create a personalized “Separation Roadmap” — target dates for applying to VA benefits or lining up job interviews.

items.subheading: Separation / Early Post-Separation (0–3 months after discharge)
content: DD-214 & VA Enrollment: Upon discharge, service members receive a DD-214. Submitting this to VA establishes eligibility for most benefits. Within 180 days post-discharge, veterans must enroll in VA healthcare to secure priority access and preserve any service-connected health needs.

Education and Training Kickoff: Many newly separated veterans submit Post-9/11 GI Bill (Chapter 33) applications or apply for Vocational Rehabilitation & Employment (Chapter 31) if they have a service-connected disability. Some enroll immediately in community college or technical schools using GI Bill funds.

Job Search & Placement: Veterans engage with their local Department of Labor (DOL) One-Stop Career Center. A Veteran Employment Program Manager (VEPM) assists with résumé reviews, interview practice, and apprenticeship referrals. VA’s VR&E (Chapter 31) program (if qualified) helps find, train for, and place veterans into suitable civilian careers.

Benefits Navigation Continues: Filing or appealing disability compensation claims via VA’s eBenefits portal. Applying for VA home loan guarantees or VA-backed mortgages. Using VA’s 'Choice' or 'MISSION Act' to see community providers when VA facilities are far away.

Career & Education Progression: Many veterans either advance in their chosen civilian field or pursue advanced degrees (bachelor’s, master’s) funded by GI Bill or Yellow Ribbon support. Some use SBA resources to start veteran-owned businesses.
Ongoing Health & Wellness: Regular engagement with VA medical centers or community care for chronic, service-connected conditions. Vet Center check-ins for PTSD or military sexual trauma support.

Community & Family Stabilization: Joining local Veteran Service Organizations (VSOs) like VFW or American Legion for peer support, advocacy, and social events. Reestablishing family routines, with VA family counseling if needed.
